appendix.title: IBM &zseries; Installation Instructions
appendix.para: &cloud; supports the &o_comp; ZVMDriver driver which manages communication between &ostack; and a z/VM hypervisor to deploy and manage &vmguest;s on z/VM. &productname; does not natively support managing and deploying z/VM &vmguest;s—it delegates requests to an &xcat; server running on z/VM. This requires a proper setup on the &zseries; side and a single ∁ node on the &cloud; side.

sect1.title: Configuring IBM &zseries;
sect1.para: IBM supports different ways to set up the &zseries; side. This document describes the CMA mn setup as described in the IBM documentation. It configures the z/VM Cloud Manager Appliance (CMA) to only run the Extreme Cloud Administration Toolkit (&xcat;) and the ZHCP services, because, all &ostack; components are running on external &cloud; servers.
Additional documentation providing in-depth information to topics also covered in this document are available from IBM and can be retrieved from the IBM Knowledge Center for z/VM 6.3.0:

para.link: z/VM Enabling z/VM for &ostack; (Support for &ostack; Liberty Release)

sect1.para: Note, that the IBM manuals contain procedures and setups not fully tested by &suse; and &cloud;. In this text, links to sections covering topics described in the IBM manuals are provided in the respective sections.
The following steps are required to set up the &zseries; side:

sect2.title: Supported Setup
sect2.para: To manage and deploy &vmguest;s on z/VM with &cloud;, a z/VM running the CMA with the &xcat; and ZHCP services is required. You also need to set up a Linux system running &cloudos; that will be used to capture an image from. The setup described in this document uses the following components and configurations:

listitem.para: The &xcat; server and the &cloud; ∁ node need to be able to bidirectionally communicate with each other. This can, for example, be achieved by assigning the &xcat; and the ∁ node IP addresses from the public cloud network. See for details.

Networking for &zseries; &vmguest;s instances is handled by the &xcat; server. See Network Considerations and the following chapters in the IBM documentation for general information. &suse; supports setting up the &xcat; server with either a single flat network or a flat and VLAN mixed network.
The Linux image capture system needs to run &cloudos; for IBM &zseries; and needs to use ECKD or FBA for storage. See for a full list of requirements for this system.
Live migration of &vmguest;s is currently not supported by &suse;.

sect2.title: Configuring z/VM
sect2.para: Please refer to The Virtualization Cookbook for IBM z Systems Volume 1: IBM z/VM 6.3 for general instructions on how to configure z/VM. The following requirements need to be fulfilled:

listitem.para: The IBM Directory Maintenance Facility (DIRMAINT) needs to be enabled
The z/VM Systems Management API (SMAPI) needs to be enabled

Provide four preformatted Model 9 (or equivalent) system attached mini disks for the CMA. These disks will be used by &xcat; and be added to the disk pool XCAT1. Refer to CMA120.FILE on mdisk 400 in MAINT for detailed instructions.

Provided two Model 3 (or equivalent) mini disks to be added to the system as M0101 and M0102. These disks are used to store the root disks of the &vmguest;s. Refer to the section Disk Storage: CMA Environment in the IBM documentation for details.

Provide a single disk pool for disk space required for the &vmguest;s. It is not possible to use more than one disk pool for this purpose. Supported pool types are ECKD or FBA. All images must use the disk type specified for this pool, mixing ECKD and FBA is not supported.
&xcat; needs to be configured to have SMAPI access. Note that in previous CMA versions, ZHCP needed to have SMAPI access. This has changed with the CMA for &ostack; Liberty.
Provide a real OSA device for &xcat;.
Make sure to the IP address for &xcat; is accessible from within the company network.

sect2.title: Capturing an Image for &slsa; on &zseries;
sect2.para: To start an &vmguest;, an operating system image is required. To create such an image, you need to set up a &cloudos; system running in the same z/VM as the CMA. Once the system has been installed and configured, you can shut it down and capture the image. In the following this Linux system used to capture the image from is referred to as the image capture system.
The following steps are required to capture an image. In case you plan to provide multiple images, these steps need to be repeated for each image.

step.para: Checking the

sect3.title: Requirements for the Image Capture System
sect3.para: The following requirements for the image capture system need to be met:

listitem.para: Use &cloudos; as an operating system. This system has been tested and is known to work. &slsa; 11 SP4 and RHEL 6.2 - 7.2 may also work but have not been tested by &suse;).

Use a minidisk with ECKD or FBA for storage. You must use the same type as is used for the disk pool for ephemeral storage, mixing ECKD and FBA is not possible. The minidisk must not be a full-pack disk and needs to be defined with the virtual address 0100.
Network interfaces need to be configured with IPv4. Disabling IPv6 in the network settings is strongly recommended.

The size of the root disk should not exceed 5 GB. It is also recommended to use a disk size with a full gigabyte value (for example 2GB or 3GB), since &ostack; disks are defined that way. See the Mainframe Disk Capacity Table for values that help to convert blocks or cylinders to bytes.
The root disk needs to have a single partition and the root file system must not be on a logical volume.
The root file system needs to be formatted with Ext2, Ext3, Ext4, or XFS. Btrfs is currently not supported.
The sshd needs to run and the SSH port (22) needs to be opened in the firewall.

sect3.title: Installing and Configuring the Image Capture System
sect3.para: To install the image capture system, follow the default &slsa; for IBM &zseries; installation instructions that are available from the &suse; Web page: Installation on IBM z Systems. Make sure to fulfill the when setting up the network and the partitions.

listitem.para: Make sure the package openssl is installed
SELinux must not be enabled (this is the default for &cloudos;)
The system needs to be accessible via SSH. Disable DNS lookup for SSH by setting UseDNS no in /etc/ssh/sshd_config.

sect3.title: Define the Image Capture System as an &xcat; Node
sect3.para: Before you can create an image for the image capture system, you need to define it as a node to the &xcat; server.

step.para: Log in to the &xcat; server via SSH as the user configured with XCAT_MN_admin and XCAT_MN_pw earlier on.
Run the following command:
step.screen: sudo /opt/xcat/bin/mkdef -t node -o HOSTNAME userid=UID \ hcp=ZHCP_FQN mgt=zvm groups=all

The userid name of the image capture system.
The fully qualified host name of the ZHCP server, for example zhcp.&exampledomain;

step.para: Update the node's properties by running the following command:
step.screen: sudo /opt/xcat/sbin/chtab node=HOSTNAME hosts.ip=IP_ADDRESS \ hosts.hostnames=FQN noderes.netboot=zvm nodetype.os=sles12.1 \ nodetype.arch=s390x nodetype.profile=PROFILENAME nodetype.provmethod=netboot

listitem.para: The image capture system's short host name, for example &wsI;
The IP address of the image capture system.

Profile name for this system, can be freely chosen.

sect3.title: Installing and Configuring Cloud-Init
sect3.para: Whenever an &vmguest; is started for the first time, the activation engine cloud-init runs to take care of the initial setup of the image. Among other things, it injects the SSH keys, that allow remote access to the &vmguest;. To make Cloud-Init available, it need to be installed and configured in the image capture system.

sect4.title: Installing Cloud-Init
sect4.para: Cloud-Init for &slsa; is available as an RPM package from the Public Cloud Module. The Public Cloud Module is included in your &slsa; subscription, but needs to be activated. To install Cloud-init, proceed as follows:

step.para: Log in to the image capture system as &rootuser;.

Launch the &yast; Product Registration . If you have not registered your system, yet, do so now and restart the Product Registration module afterwards.
2016-10-17 - fs: We have a catch22 problem here: We do not want the root image to already be registered, however, access to the Public Cloud Module is only available when the system is registered. How to solve this problem?
Click Select Extensions to open the Extension and Module Selection dialog. Select Public Cloud Module 12 x86_64 and proceed with Next.

After the module has been registered and the repository data has been downloaded, the software manager opens with two packages preselected for installation. Switch to the Search tab, enter cloud-init into the text box and click Search.
The package cloud-init will be listed in the right-hand pane. Select it and proceed with Accept. Confirm the Automatic Changes with Continue to start the package installation.
Finalize the installation by clicking Finish. Cloud-Init is now available on the installation capture system.

sect4.title: Configuring and Activating Cloud-Init
sect4.para: To finalize the setup of the image capture system, Cloud-Init needs to be configured and its associated services need to be started.

step.para: Log in as user &rootuser; to the image capture system.
The Cloud-Init configuration is stored in /etc/cloud/cloud.cfg. Open this file in an editor and make the following adjustments:
Add the following lines underneath the section that is titled # Adapted default config for (open)SUSE systems:
step.screen:
# Datasource configuration
datasource_list: [ ConfigDrive, None ] datasource: ConfigDrive: dsmode: local

step.para: Navigate to the section titled # The modules that run in the 'init' stage. Remove the modules growpart, and resizefs. Add the module seed_random. After the change the section should look like the following:
step.screen: # The modules that run in the 'init' stage cloud_init_modules: - migrator - seed_random - bootcmd - write-files - set_hostname - update_hostname - update_etc_hosts - ca-certs - rsyslog - users-groups - ssh

step.para: Navigate to the section titled # The modules that run in the 'config' stage. Remove the modules ssh-import-id, chef, and byobu. Add the module disk_setup. After the change the section should look like the following:
step.screen: # The modules that run in the 'config' stage cloud_config_modules: - disk_setup - mounts - locale - set-passwords - package-update-upgrade-install - timezone - puppet - salt-minion - mcollective - disable-ec2-metadata - runcmd

step.para: For more optional configuration options (such as defining a default user or setting up sudo, refer to .
Create the file /etc/tmpfiles.d/cloud-init-tmpfiles.conf with the following command:
Start and enable the Cloud-Init services:
step.screen: for SERV in cloud-init cloud-ini-local cloud-config cloud-final; do systemctl enable $SERV systemctl start $SERV systemctl status $SERV echo "---------------------" done
step.para: Carefully check the output of these commands to make sure the services are active and running. In case one of the services fails, try restarting it.
Remove the directory /var/lib/cloud, otherwise Cloud-Init will not run when first booting an &vmguest;:

sect4.para: The image capture system setup and configuration is now finished.

sect2.title: Exporting and Uploading an Image for IBM &zseries; to &o_img;
sect2.para: To make the image that was created following the instructions in available in &cloud; it needs to be exported to the &compnode; and then be uploaded to &o_img;.

step.screen: openstack image create --name="IMAGE_NAME" --progress \ --visibility=public --disk-format=raw --container-format=bare \ --property image_type_xcat=linux --property architecture=s390x \ --property os_name=Linux --property os_version=sles12.2 \ --property provisioning_method=netboot < ~nova/IMAGE_FILE_NAME

sect2.title: Create an &xcat; Management Provider Network
sect2.para: The last step that is required before you can start an &vmguest; is to set up the &xcat; provider management network in &crow;. This network is required for communication between the &xcat; host and the &vmguest;s.

step.para: Log in as &rootuser; to one of the &contrnode;s.
Source the .openrc file:
Create the network:
Replace the following placeholders with appropriate values:

listitem.para: Name for the management network, can be freely chosen, for example xcat_mgmt.
Switch that was configured with XCAT_MN_vswitch in DMSSICNF COPY (see ). Should be xcatvsw2 if you have not changed the default as was recommended.
Create a subnet:
listitem.screen: neutron subnet-create xcat_mgmt --gateway GATEWAY \ XCAT_MGMT_NETWORK --allocation-pool start=START,end=END \ --disable-dhcp

step.para: Replace the following placeholders with appropriate values:

listitem.para: IP address of the gateway of the &xcat; management network.
Address of the &xcat; management network, for example 192.168.2.0/24.

Define the range of IP addresses to use for the subnet by defining a start and end address. Make sure to exclude addresses that are already in use, such as the address used by the &xcat; server itself.
